Oksana Boyko: Hello and welcome to Worlds
Apart. Politics is an art of compromise, or

5.79.text:
at least it used to be. In the current standoff
between Russia and the West over the Ukraine,

10.26.text:
both sides accuse each other of intransigence
and keep raising the stakes. After years of

15.12.text:
paying lip service to the non-zero sum approach,
are we back to the geopolitics of all or nothing?

21.00.text:
Well to discuss that, I'm now joined by one
of the world's most senior statesmen and a

25.31.text:
former Australian prime minister, Malcolm
Fraser. Mr Fraser, thank you very much for

31.51.text:
OB: Now, we are hearing a lot these days about
the prospect of another Cold War, and you

36.61.text:
actually lived through the original Cold War.
Do you think a re-run is possible?

41.48.text:
MF: A new Cold War is certainly possible and
it's easy to cast blame or the situation that

50.32.text:
has arisen. I think NATO missed a great opportunity
with the breakup of the Soviet Union. I know

59.32.text:
President Gorbachev believed he had an agreement
with the first Bush administration that NATO

66.41.text:
would not move east. NATO had, after all,
done it's job. But then it pushed ahead to

73.00.text:
the borders of Russia, and I can understand
Russians believing that that's a provocative

80.71.text:
move. There would have been other ways, less
provocative ways, of ensuring the security

86.93.text:
and independence of eastern European states.
I think the West then lost an opportunity

96.08.text:
to really begin to make Russia a collaborative
partner.

100.58.text:
OB: Mr Fraser, you just mentioned that those
inroads into Russia's immediate neighbourhood

106.93.text:
by NATO are seen in Moscow as provocative
but when Russia expresses those concerns,

111.61.text:
they are usually taken as paranoid in the
West. And even if we accept them as such,

117.69.text:
as paranoid, what's the point from the western
perspective of pushing a paranoid Russia to

124.39.text:
MF: I don't believe Russia is paranoid. I
do believe Russia has historic interests and

131.39.text:
this was certainly a traditional area of Russian
interest long, long, preceding communism and

141.07.text:
Stalin. And the United States in particular
said no, this is going to become an area of

147.78.text:
western influence, of NATO influence, European
influence or American influence. And I can

154.80.text:
understand Russia being greatly disturbed
about this.

160.52.text:
OB: You just mentioned a moment ago that Gorbachev,
Mikhail Gorbachev, was promised by NATO officials

167.20.text:
that after the collapse of the Berlin Wall,
NATO expansion would essentially stop, and

172.39.text:
yet we all know that that didn't happen. Why
do you think the West and NATO, in particular,

177.00.text:
have been so persistent in moving eastward,
because we had almost three generations of

184.35.text:
western policy makers who have never questioned
the wisdom or indeed, potential ramifications

190.75.text:
MF: There are many people, I think, who have
questioned the move west of, the move eastward

197.10.text:
of NATO, but president Clinton was determined
that it should happen. He believed that putting

204.95.text:
eastern European states within NATO would
be a democratising move. I can't see how he

214.97.text:
arrives at that particular logic. NATO had
done its job. I think the Soviet Union, from

223.73.text:
my perspective, was a outward looking, thrusting,
aggressive power. But then when it disintegrated,

230.65.text:
the West should have done everything it could
to build a collaborative world, to make sure

236.72.text:
that, alright, Russia no longer had it's Soviet
empire, but Russia is a very important country,

244.63.text:
how can we make sure that we can work with
Russia, that Russia will want to work with

249.83.text:
us? Well, pushing NATO to the boundaries of
Russia, in my view, was bound to do the opposite.

257.48.text:
OB: Now Moscow's concerns over the expansion
of NATO have long been dismissed in the West

263.38.text:
as the example of the Cold War mentality,
you know, that Russia still lives in the past

268.96.text:
and views the West in those Cold War lenses.
And yet if we look at the current crisis and

274.51.text:
the way it was portrayed in the West, many
suggested that Russia's effective control

280.21.text:
over Crimea is just the first step in Putin's
expansionist, imperialistic agenda and that

287.08.text:
if he's not challenged this time around, the
next day he will invade Poland, and the day

292.43.text:
after tanks may role into the Czech Republic.
I wonder, how do you think we can break this

297.68.text:
cycle of mutual fears that over time turn
into self-fulfilling prophecies?

303.65.text:
MF: Somehow or other, Russia and the West
need to try and make a new start, a different

310.60.text:
start. I think we have to accept that what
the European Union has done over recent years,

318.74.text:
what's happened in the Crimea, these things
have happened. But how do we re-establish

325.96.text:
a degree of trust between the West, between
NATO and between Russia? Because without a

333.33.text:
degree of trust, there's not going to be any
peace and there will be a return to a cold

338.83.text:
war. Now, I could make a suggestion. The West,
it seems to me, and European Union and NATO

348.17.text:
in particular, have been trying to woo Ukraine,
a traditional area of Russian interest, or

356.75.text:
of concern, not over a few years, not over
the period of communism, but over centuries.

365.21.text:
And they're trying to woo the Ukraine, really,
to say 'we want to join NATO'. I think the

372.54.text:
Ukraine should be told that it can never join
NATO, that other means will be found to make

378.33.text:
sure that the Ukraine remains secure. The
West should be persuading those who are now

385.50.text:
in government in the Ukraine that within Ukraine
they must learn the art of compromise. And

395.53.text:
those who are more inclined to Russia in the
Ukraine, should also be persuaded by Russia

401.79.text: – you must also learn the art of compromise.

405.31.text:
OB: But Mr Fraser you certainly cannot teach
Ukraine the art of compromise without Russia

411.21.text:
and the West exercising that art themselves,
and it seems that at the moment, the exchange,

417.42.text:
the political exchange between the two, is
quite uncompromising, lets say so. Now, I

423.20.text:
know that just a few days ago, you published
an article, an op-ed, in The Guardian in which

429.94.text:
you said that there's absolutely no way out
of the current crisis, unless the West recognises

435.00.text:
some of its past mistakes that you ave already
mentioned, that is, the expansion of NATO.

439.96.text:
But recognising one's mistakes is an extremely
difficult thing to do. Do you think the current

445.98.text:
generation of policy makers, decision makers,
in the West have got what it takes to concede

452.73.text: some of the weaknesses of their policies?

454.52.text:
MF: Well, this might be one of the problems
of the world. Where are the great leaders?

461.38.text:
Where are the great statesmen? After the world
war, I think there were many people that realised

466.81.text:
that the world nearly destroyed itself. And
victors and vanquished all determined to do

473.07.text:
better to try and create a safer and a more
secure world, but where do such people exist

478.94.text:
today? I think that's a very real question.
I don't know that we should talk about the

486.61.text:
past, or continue to. Events have moved on
since that article was published a little.

493.03.text:
The referendum in the Crimea has been taken
and I would believe that most people feel

501.14.text:
that Crimea, whether as an independent state,
or whether it's joining Russia, is no longer

510.07.text:
really part of Ukraine. Everyone should understand,
including the West, that the naval facilities,

519.93.text:
the military facilities, in Crimea were absolutely
essential to Russia, and that Russia would

527.00.text:
have to take action to secure and safeguard
those particular strategic interests. Now,

537.15.text:
having arrived at this point, how do we move
on? And moving on does not consist of encouraging

545.42.text:
one of the major parties in the Ukraine, hosted
by President Obama just a day or two ago in

553.70.text:
the White House, that that party can have
it all its own way. So if both the West and

562.49.text:
Russia say 'right, we've got to try and establish
the circumstances so that people in the Ukraine

569.55.text:
can live at peace with themselves'. At the
moment, that's not happening.

574.58.text:
OB: Yeah, I agree with you totally. There
is a saying by a famous American economist,

581.77.text:
John Kenneth Galbraith, who said once: 'politics
it the art of choosing between the disastrous

588.82.text:
and the unpalatable' and I guess that describes
the predicament of Russia and the West in

594.55.text:
the current crisis. Now, as far as Putin is
concerned, I think he chose the unpalatable.

600.64.text:
He fully understood, in my view at least,
what kind of reaction Crimea's reunification

605.75.text:
with Russia would provoke but he saw no other
way of defending Russia's national interests.

611.31.text:
Now, I would like to ask you about the western
position, this very hasty endorsement of the

617.29.text:
new Ukrainian authorities, including some
very unsavoury elements within their ranks

622.19.text:
- the ultranationalist, far-right groups.
Is it disastrous or simply unpalatable?

628.59.text:
MF: It was certainly ill-advised but this
has been done. What we now have to try and

640.46.text:
do, or what Russia, I believe, and the West
need to try and do if peace is to be maintained,

648.58.text:
and if there can be a degree of trust established,
is to persuade both the parties in the Ukraine

656.74.text:
that they must learnt the at of compromise.
The current government doesn't, to me, have

663.99.text:
a great deal of credibility because it was,
really, installed after great violence and

670.14.text:
a coup from the streets. But, alright, it
happens to be there. But if there could be

677.27.text:
elections across the Ukraine, properly supervised,
properly monitored, across the whole country,

684.65.text:
and then you have a situation in which the
European Union, the United States and Russia

693.95.text:
are all saying to those who are most friendly
to them in the Ukraine itself: 'look, if you

703.44.text:
want one country, you've got to learn to live
together. Take this opportunity to establish

710.46.text:
a parliament that will be your government'.
And then I think you'd also need to say that

720.39.text:
Ukraine should be free to make whatever economic
relationships it likes with other countries,

726.49.text:
whether Russia or the West or both, but it
should not become part of a defence bloc,

732.77.text:
a military block, and therefore, as Henry
Kissinger said a few days ago, it should not

740.40.text:
be eligible to join NATO. I think that would
be absolutely essential to gain Russian support

750.02.text:
for such a proposal because if I were Russian,
I would believe that NATO has been trying

756.30.text:
to seduce the Ukraine, although it's friendly
to the West, to force the situation so that

762.37.text: the Ukraine will become part of NATO.

765.00.text:
OB: Mr Fraser, it's refreshing to see yourself
and Henry Kissinger, people we would normally

770.58.text:
describe as 'cold warriors' advocate a sensible
compromise in this very difficult situation

778.02.text:
while the current generation of Western policy
makers seem to be very inflexible and going

784.01.text:
for the one side takes all approach. Anyway,
we have to take a short break now. When we

come back, despite the chorus of Western condemnations,
Russia has recognised the results of the Crimean

referendum. Is this a gross violation of international
law or simply history repeating itself? That's

802.57.text: coming up in a few moments on Worlds Apart.

OB: Welcome back to Worlds Apart where we
are discussing the tensions between the West

and Russia with former Australian Prime Minister
Malcolm Fraser. Mr Fraser, just to give our

in politics, you first ran for office in 1954,

that's actually the year when Nikita Khrushchev
decided to, you know, hand Crimea over to

Ukraine. And last week as we mentioned, the
people of Crimea decided to re-join Russia

and in justifying their stance, they're citing
all sorts of, what they see as, international

precedents in Kosovo, the upcoming referendum
in Scotland and so on and so forth but the

response that they're hearing from the West
is that, you know, you shouldn't mic those

1009.54.text:
things. What you are doing is illegitimate
but what we've been doing is totally right

1014.19.text:
and I wonder if you could help our viewers
understand what is so strikingly different

1020.02.text:
MF: Let me answer that this way – from the
very beginning, the United States has regarded

1026.99.text:
itself as an exceptional nation, as a nation
that's better than all others, that has only

1035.03.text:
ever gone to war to fight for the freedom
of other people. Well that's not really true,

1040.33.text:
if you look at American history. America feels
it can break international law, that what

1047.03.text:
America does is right. Rules are made for
other people, for countries like Russia or

1053.76.text:
countries like Australia, but whatever America
does is right because America does it. Now

1060.96.text:
that's in the American psyche, it's in their
DNA. There's no, the worst war that, tragically,

1072.26.text:
Australia supported was the invasion of Iraq
and all the damage, all the civilians killed

1079.00.text:
as a consequence of that – that was a total
violation of international law. And so people

1087.36.text:
just get up and say those things, and you'll
have a lot of people in the West agreeing

1092.29.text:
with President Obama simply because he says
it.

1095.27.text:
OB: Well, Mr Fraser, if I can put it to you
– one other initiative, American initiative

1102.62.text:
to some extent, that Australia has supported

1108.67.text:
of East Timor, something that led to a very

1115.23.text:
of lives, and I know that it was primarily

1122.29.text:
you know, military supplies and diplomatic

1126.85.text:
was also criticised for, well, allegedly cooperating
with the Indonesian military and President

1133.20.text:
Suharto. I wonder if, in hindsight, you ever
came to regret that policy?

MF: I regret greatly what happened in East
Timor. I believe Australia acting alone would

1145.20.text:
not have been able to do very much about it.
You mentioned American support for what Indonesia

1150.96.text:
was then doing. Now, actions of a different
Australian prime minister, and East Timor

1157.63.text:
is now independent, is now free. So, great
powers very often, too often, interpret international

1168.30.text:
law as what is in their particular interest
at the time. Now, we need to try to make rules

1176.48.text:
that everyone will support. If the United
Nations is ever to work, great powers and

1183.51.text:
lesser powers are all going to have to abide
by the rules of the organisation. But it's

1189.72.text:
the great powers that tend to push the rules
aside when it suits their national interests.

1196.60.text:
And therefore, when the United States says
that what Russia has done is in defiance of

1201.76.text:
international law, well, that can't be taken
as gospel. The government and the change of

1210.86.text:
power in Ukraine itself was surely in defiance
of democratic principles.

1217.62.text:
OB: Now, if I can draw one more parallel between
what happened in East Timor and the current

1222.62.text:
situation in Ukraine. The conflict in East
Timor was born out of the Cold War dynamic

1231.00.text:
because the West then feared that East Timor
may become a communist country and that could

1235.99.text:
be threatening to Western submarines. And
I think there are some parallels with what

1243.15.text:
is happening in Crimea, at least in the sense
that it is also a battle for the spheres of

1248.49.text:
influence and security issues, security concerns
are also at play here, but of course the population

1255.36.text:
of Crimea voted in favour of joining Russia
but some Ukrainian politicians have already

1261.63.text:
warned that it could also lead to a bloody
insurgency. Maybe not on the level that we

1266.78.text:

think there's any appetite in the West to

1272.77.text:
support any kind of anti-Russian insurgency?
Do you think that sort of Cold War tactics

1278.69.text: are still being used these days?

1280.80.text:
MF: I would hope not. I would hope the West
can learn that that kind of activity does

1286.42.text:
not really work, it destroys trust and might
make peace between Russia and other countries

1297.98.text:
quite impossible. The West should not, under
any circumstances, involve itself militarily

1308.21.text: in the affairs of Crimea, Ukraine.

1310.42.text:
OB: What you say is quite surprising for a
western statesman, a western politician. I

1316.31.text:
know that Australia is a great democracy,
you're accustomed to have all sorts of debates

1321.19.text:
on various issues but its surprising to me
that on this particular case, on this standoff

1326.60.text:
between Russia and the West, most of your
politicians across the political spectrum

1330.83.text:
are very unanimous in believing that it's
all Russia's fault, and you're pretty much

1336.55.text:
the only person of national prominence who
came out and suggested a bit more nuanced

1345.06.text:
approached to this issue. Why do you think
the Australian political elites side so blindly

1352.17.text:
MF: Newspapers report things in certain ways.
President Putin has had a bad press in the

1359.13.text:
Western media for a very long while. I think
some of this is deliberate, but I'm not the

1366.37.text:
only one whose taken a slightly different
view of events. Henry Kissinger's article,

1374.17.text:
I think in the Washington Post, was also quite
different from the general rhetoric that you

1381.38.text:
would hear from the West. A man called Cavan
Hogue, who was our last ambassador to the

1387.51.text:
Soviet Union and our first ambassador to Russia,
has also just printed an article which takes

1395.98.text:
a reasonable, balanced, point of view quite
similar to the views that I've been expressing

1404.92.text:
OB: Now, Mr Fraser you just mentioned that
President Putin has been receiving a lot of

1409.85.text:
bad press in the West, including Australia,
and I wonder why do you think the West finds

1416.60.text:
him so disagreeable? Because as it seems from
Moscow, he actually, his rhetoric has been

1421.50.text:
quite conciliatory. He actually, as far as
I'm concerned, he tried not to spoil the relations

1427.12.text:
with the West completely but for some reason
he is almost portrayed in those demonic colours

1434.01.text:
in the West. Why is he so disliked by Western
politicians and by the Western public?

1439.70.text:
MF: Western countries, Western politicians
have contributed to this, have been very short

1446.66.text:
sighted and have been incapable of looking
at the larger picture. Whether they have played

1454.71.text:
into what they think is populist sentiment
or not, I don't know. But, it's very important

1460.89.text:
that the West, European Union, America and
Russia, and China also, all get on together

1469.94.text:
and that's essential if there's going to be
a peaceful world. And therefore, you don't

1474.95.text:
do things that are going to create mistrust.
Now, President Putin said something about

1480.48.text:
the anti-ballistic missile facilities that
the second President Bush wanted to place

1487.11.text:
in Poland and, I think, Czechoslovakia. He
claimed they were aimed at Iran. Well if I

1492.64.text:
were Russian, I would say they're not aimed
at Iran, they're aimed at Russia. And that

1498.05.text:
I would have regarded as a hostile move compounding
NATO's move to the boundaries of Russia. You've

1507.59.text:
got to try and build a better world, you've
got to try and built trust. And you don't

1514.62.text:
do that by behaving as though a Cold War is
still in place. Now, putting those ABM sites

1522.65.text:
in those two countries, to me, was behaving
as though the Cold War was still alive and

1529.46.text:
well. Shifting NATO east, even though President
Gorbachev believed he had an agreement that

1536.83.text:
it should not. I think he was wrong in that
but he had certainly argued for it very strongly.

1543.36.text:
I think doing that was a provocation and not
conducive to establishing the kind of trust

1550.66.text:
and cooperation which is so necessary if there
is to be a real peace and real cooperation.

1557.25.text:
OB: You just mentioned China as an important
player and what's interesting to me is that

1562.60.text:
in your op-ed in The Guardian, you also mentioned
China as the country that has been facing

1568.82.text:
this policy of containment from the United
States rather than the policy of engagement

1574.27.text:
and cooperation that you advocate for, and
I'm sure Chinese, like Russians, have increasingly

1582.15.text:
less tolerance for this language of force.
Do you see that as a source of potential tension,

1588.83.text:
probably similar to the ones that we've seen
these days over Ukraine?

1593.45.text:
MF: Well, the United States speaks with two
voices to China. On the one hand, they say

1599.25.text:
they want strategic cooperation, they want
economic cooperation, social cooperation,

1605.11.text:
and on the other hand, they tighten, they
strengthen their defences, from Japan south

1612.14.text:
through Australia, around Singapore and even
now talking of making India a strategic partner.

1620.68.text:
My Chinese friends say: 'which America are
we to believe? The one that talks cooperation

1627.59.text:
or the one that's seeking to strengthen it's
already very powerful military forces?' And

1634.79.text:
we shouldn't forget, in these circumstances,
that China's military expenditure is about

1641.06.text:
eight percent of the world's total. America's
is about 42% of the world's total. The balance

1647.81.text:
of military expenditure overwhelmingly, it's
American. And is that the way to build peace?

1656.87.text:
America tried in Vietnam, they tried in Iraq,
they're trying in Afghanistan as Russia did,

1665.19.text:
and all three are going to end as failures.
So, the United States hasn't come to understand

1673.80.text:
that a good political outcome is very difficult
to obtain through military means.

1679.82.text:
OB: Mr Fraser, in just a few moments that
we have left – you are one of the few remaining

1687.17.text:
Cold War veterans, and you said previously
that 'Those who thought the Cold War was over

1695.35.text:
and who hoped for a better world are now being
proved wrong'. Is it really that bad?

1702.35.text:
MF: You have to be an optimist. We have to
hope for a better world and leaders who will

1711.50.text:
OB: Well, Mr Fraser, one thing I know for

1716.23.text:
we just had wouldn’t be possible during
the Cold War. So, I really appreciate you

1720.83.text:
being on the show, unfortunately we have to
leave it there.

1724.27.text:
OB: And to our viewers, please keep the conversation

pages and I hope to see you again, same place,
